conclusion: The y-axis represents velocity in meters per second and the x-axis represents time in seconds.
At t = 0 to t = 1 s, the velocity is constant at v = 2 m·s⁻¹.
At t = 1 s, the velocity starts decreasing.
At t = 2 s, the velocity reaches v = 0 m·s⁻¹.
From t = 2 s to t = 3 s, the velocity continues to decrease linearly to v = -2 m·s⁻¹.
We need to find the acceleration from t = 1 s to t = 3 s.
During the interval from t = 1 s to t = 3 s, the velocity changes from v = 2 m·s⁻¹ to v = -2 m·s⁻¹.
The graph shows a straight line with a negative slope from t = 1 s to t = 3 s, indicating constant acceleration.
Change in velocity (Δv) = v_f - v_i = -2 - 2 = -4 m·s⁻¹.
Acceleration (a) is calculated as a = Δv/Δt = -4/2 = -2 m·s⁻².
The negative sign indicates that the acceleration is in the opposite direction to the initial velocity.
The acceleration of the particle during the time interval from 1 to 3 seconds is -2 m·s⁻².
